results.title: Computers: where they come from & how they work
results.creator_credit: E F S Productions, Disney Educational Productions, Rick Rothschild and Scott Hennesy
results.brief_description: An entertaining animated look at the history of the computer. This short video is suitable for children in the middle to upper primary age group.

results.title: Computers: The Friendly Invasion (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Extraordinary computer, graphics and spectacular scenes from the terrific Disney feature “Tron” illustrate dazzling computer applications and introduce students to a fabulous resource. You will learn how people working with computers, can build a better world in the future.

results.title: Computers, spies and private lives
results.creator_credit: Time-Life Video, Theodore Bogosian and Linda Harrar
results.brief_description: Reveals how computers that are routinely gathering information on our finances, politics, tastes and habits may pose a threat to our individual privacy.

results.title: Computers in the seventies
results.brief_description: This film takes a pre-micro-chip look at computer development to the 1970s providing a short historical background and then examining contemporary computer development in meteorology, records storage, aviation and building design, and medical procedures. Touches on contemporary times with “suspicion”.

results.title: Computers in accounting
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Ministry of Education, George Cass and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Shows some of the ways in which computer technology is being used in accounting firms and examines the impact of this on small business. Some of the problems encountered by small business when installing a new computer system are discussed. Also looks at the training needed by young people seeking employment in the accounting profession.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Ministry of Education, George Cass and Jeff Spencer

results.title: Computers and you
results.creator_credit: Journal Films and Reinald Werrenrath Jr
results.brief_description: In this film a computer display terminal and diagrams are used to explain, in simple terms, how a computer works and what it can do. A clear, visual explanation of how “bits” of information are given and instructions, flow charts, and information storage methods are explained. Suitable for teachers and tertiary level students.

results.title: Computers
results.creator_credit: Bailey Film Productions and Victor and Ellen Landweber
results.brief_description: Describes the major components of a modern digital computer, and explores how the binary number system is useful in computer technology. The computer makes very rapid computations, and stores vast quantities of information.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bailey Film Productions and Victor and Ellen Landweber

results.title: Computer: tool for the future
results.creator_credit: National Geographic Society, Sidney Platt and Yves Gerard Issembert
results.brief_description: A look at the history of tools such as the abacus, adding machines and computers, the recent developments in computer technology and how computers are used to manage information and various applications of computers today. Also mentions some of the concerns that computerization raises.

results.title: Computer history digest: a chronicle of important events...
results.creator_credit: Association for computing machinery and George Samson
results.brief_description: Provides a brief historical overview of computers, with a focus on US achievements. Discusses punch card technology and the flexibility of plug boards. Shows the 1939 Worlds Fair showcasing future calculating devices and the ENIAC, designed by Eckert and Mauchly to compute World War II ballistic firing tables. Includes early 20th century footage of computers.
